--- title: Python --- # Why Python? ## On Python * Python is free, * Python is very widely used, * Python is flexible, * Python is relatively easy to learn, * and Python is quite powerful. ## Why not Python? - Python is a general purpose language used for Scientific Computing. - _Not_ to build apps, build software, manage databases, or develop user interfaces. - Solve scientific and mathematical problems. ## Python libraries Scientists often use the following: * [Python](https://www.python.org/), * [`numpy` (numerical Python)](https://www.numpy.org/), * [`matplotlib` (a suite of plotting tools)](https://matplotlib.org/), * [`scipy` (scientific Python)](https://www.scipy.org/), and * [`sympy` (symbolic Python)](https://www.sympy.org/en/index.html). We'll get to these. # Running Example ## Diving In - Taking Python as a given, we'll: - Use an example of something I helped a student with recently - Show step-by-step how to use Python - Introduce a number of Python features to solve the problem more easily. - This was from an introductory physics class I believe; I don't know the context. ## Motivating Example - Recently, I helped a student stuck on this: $$ f(x) = \begin{cases} 9x^2 + 5 & x < 4 \\ 9 & 4 \leq x \leq 8 \\ 2 - x & x > 8 \end{cases} $$ - Find $f(x)$ for each of the following $x$ values: $$ \{-1, 4, 5, 8, 11\} $$ ## Is this "real"? - Models income tax brackets, one of the most important drivers of human behavior in the largest economies in the world. - We use a simpler contrived example for now...

## How to solve? - Think about how you would solve such a problem. - What steps would you take? - What would making solving it hard? - Keep track of details? - Performing the arithmetic? - Anything else? - Python, in my view, is a way to solve these problems. ## Python in action - My preferred way to do calculation as an experienced Python user is writing *code*: :::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="50%"} - Mathematical expression $$ \begin{cases} 9x^2 + 5 & x < 4 \\ 9 & 4 \leq x \leq 8 \\ 2 - x & x > 8 \end{cases} $$ ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} - Python expression (code) ::: {#d22c6495 .cell execution_count=2} ``` {.python .cell-code} 9 * -1 * -1 + 5 ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=476} ``` 14 ``` ::: ::: ::: :::: - I write `x * x` for $x^2$ because it's non-obvious how to write "squared" yet. ## Arithmetic Operations - In Python, we can write many of the same arithmetic operations we use in our math and science classes. ::: {#5a562a83 .cell execution_count=3} ``` {.python .cell-code} 6 + 3 ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=477} ``` 9 ``` ::: ::: ::: {#d241dde6 .cell execution_count=4} ``` {.python .cell-code} 6 - 3 ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=478} ``` 3 ``` ::: ::: ::: {#3d6e698a .cell execution_count=5} ``` {.python .cell-code} 6 * 3 ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=479} ``` 18 ``` ::: ::: ::: {#059023f8 .cell execution_count=6} ``` {.python .cell-code} 6 / 3 ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=480} ``` 2.0 ``` ::: ::: ## Wait? - Use Python? How? - To use Python to make this calculation, first we must install Python. - It is a program, like Firefox, MS Word or Fortnite # Installing Python ## Warning! - There is a very important box to check while installing! - Be careful working ahead! - We'll teach how to fix not checking this box *but not for a while* ## Installation - We go to the offial webpage to get an installer for our computer: - [https://www.python.org/downloads/](https://www.python.org/downloads/) - Be careful about starting it! - You can open it and check the next slide. ## Add Python to PATH ![](img/add-python-to-path.png) ## Why? - The benefit of adding Python to path is that we can use it at - <dramatic music> - *The Command Line* - A text-based interface to computing resources, including its ability to do e.g. arithmetic and save notes. ## Terminal - On MS Windows - I press Windows key, type "terminal" then press enter. - On MacOS - I open Launchpad, type "terminal" then press enter. ## MacOS ![](img/zsh.png) ## Windows ![](img/ps.webp) ## Expression evaluation - Returning to the terminal, we can type at the "prompt". - On MacOS, perhaps a line that begins with `$` and a flashing cursor - On Window, perhaps `PS C:\Users\calvin>` - `PS` stands for "powershell" - more latter. - `C:\Users\calvin` is the name of a folder - more latter - `>` is the prompt, with a flashing cursor. ## "Run" Python *In the following examples, I remove line numbers to denote they are not Python code snippets.* - On Windows, type `python` ```{.ps filename="Windows" code-line-numbers="false"} PS C:\Users\calvin> python ``` - On MacOS, type `python3` ```{.zsh filename="MacOS" code-line-numbers="false"} $ python3 ``` - On both, press the **↵ᴇɴᴛᴇʀ** key. ## See Python - You'll see something like this: ```{.email code-line-numbers="false"} Python 3.12.5 (tags/v3.12.5:ff3bc82, Aug 6 2024, 20:45:27) [MSC v.1940 64 bit (AMD64)] on win32 Type "help", "copyright", "credits" or "license" for more information. >>> ``` - Take note of the prompt! - `>>>` - Those three are how you know it is Python, and not the Terminal, that you are working in. ## Example - If I type `python` at the command line - Then `9 * -1 * -1 + 5` *within* Python - It will look like this: ```{.email code-line-numbers="false"} PS C:\Users\calvin> python Python 3.12.5 (tags/v3.12.5:ff3bc82, Aug 6 2024, 20:45:27) [MSC v.1940 64 bit (AMD64)] on win32 Type "help", "copyright", "credits" or "license" for more information. >>> 9 * -1 * -1 + 5 14 >>> ``` - This is how Python shows that `9 * -1 * -1 + 5` is `14` # Evaluating Expressions ## Recall :::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="50%"} $$ \begin{cases} 9x^2 + 5 & x < 4 \\ 9 & 4 \leq x \leq 8 \\ 2 - x & x > 8 \end{cases} $$ $$ \{-1, 4, 5, 8, 11\} $$ ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} ```{.python code-line-numbers="false"} >>> 9 * -1 * -1 + 5 14 >>> 9 9 >>> 9 9 >>> 9 9 >>> 2 - 11 -9 ``` ::: :::: - This is still quite tedious and annoying! ## (In)equality testing - Like `+` or `-` which we use to calculate numbers... - We can use `<` or `>` to calculate inequalities. - Specifically, we see whether an inequality is `True` or `False` ::: {#98af8eae .cell execution_count=7} ``` {.python .cell-code} -1 < 4 ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=481} ``` True ``` ::: ::: ::: {#403a7175 .cell execution_count=8} ``` {.python .cell-code} 4 < 4 ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=482} ``` False ``` ::: ::: ## Accomodating Keyboards - Some things aren't super easy to type. - I don't have a "$\leq$" key on my keyboard. - Combine with `=` as `<=` for "less than or equal" or "$\leq$" ::: {#15f4a159 .cell execution_count=9} ``` {.python .cell-code} 4 <= 4 ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=483} ``` True ``` ::: ::: - We can "chain" inequalities as well - one after another. ::: {#8a85781c .cell execution_count=10} ``` {.python .cell-code} 4 <= 4 <= 8 ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=484} ``` True ``` ::: ::: ## A note - We always put the equal sign `=` second. ::: {#82cbc62b .cell execution_count=11} ``` {.python .cell-code} 4 <= 5 ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=485} ``` True ``` ::: ::: ::: {#73052195 .cell execution_count=12} ``` {.python .cell-code} 5 >= 4 ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=486} ``` True ``` ::: ::: - A (somewhat confusing) error if we try `=>` ```{.email code-line-numbers="false"} >>> 4 => 5 File "", line 1 4 => 5 ^ SyntaxError: cannot assign to literal ``` # `=` and `==` ## New Topics - We have now touch on two new topics: - `True` and `False` - Expressions which don't *evaluate* to a number - Called "booleans" - "Assignment" - Associated with the `=` sign - Different from inequality testing! - We'll explore both! ## Booleans - Sometimes, a Python *expression* is a numerical value. ::: {#666345c9 .cell execution_count=13} ``` {.python .cell-code} 2 + 2 ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=487} ``` 4 ``` ::: ::: ::: {#a4a8eb9d .cell execution_count=14} ``` {.python .cell-code} 7 ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=488} ``` 7 ``` ::: ::: - But it doesn't have to be! ::: {#34534aa9 .cell execution_count=15} ``` {.python .cell-code} 2 < 2 ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=489} ``` False ``` ::: ::: ## If - Booleans are mostly useful for writing `if` statements. - These are *multiline* expressions in Python. - To see the result of multi-line expression, we have to print the result... ::: {#c3b54b1f .cell execution_count=16} ``` {.python .cell-code} if (1 <= 1): print(2 + 2) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` 4 ``` ::: ::: ::: {#a6468b89 .cell execution_count=17} ``` {.python .cell-code} if (1 < 1): print(2 + 2) ``` ::: ## Piecewise - We can see the immediate use of this in a piecewise function! :::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="50%"} $$ \begin{cases} 9x^2 + 5 & x < 4 \\ 9 & 4 \leq x \leq 8 \\ 2 - x & x > 8 \end{cases} $$ $$ \{-1, 4, 5, 8, 11\} $$ ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} ::: {#149f0c69 .cell execution_count=18} ``` {.python .cell-code} if (-1 < 4): print(9 * -1 * -1 + 5) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` 14 ``` ::: ::: - Or least part of one... ::: {#030deea0 .cell execution_count=19} ``` {.python .cell-code} if (4 < 4): print(9 * 4 * 4 + 5) ``` ::: - Uh oh! ::: :::: ## Else - Oftentimes, we use `if` with `else` ::: {#b319e78f .cell execution_count=20} ``` {.python .cell-code} if (1 < 1): print("1 is less than 1") else: print("1 is not less than 1") ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` 1 is not less than 1 ``` ::: ::: ## Elif - If we have more than two options, we can place a special `elif` in the middle. :::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="50%"} ::: {#f383f316 .cell execution_count=21} ``` {.python .cell-code} if (1 < 1): print("1 is less than 1") elif (1 > 1): print("1 is greater than 1") else: print("1 is equal to 1") ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` 1 is equal to 1 ``` ::: ::: ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} ::: {#506c3146 .cell execution_count=22} ``` {.python .cell-code} if (2 < 1): print("2 is less than 1") elif (2 > 1): print("2 is greater than 1") else: print("2 is equal to 1") ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` 2 is greater than 1 ``` ::: ::: ::: :::: - By the way, it is extremely obnoxious to manually type `2` in *5 different places* ## Assignment - We can also assign variables! - I call this *single-equals assignment* - Use a single equals sign `=` and some variable name, like `x` :::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="50%"} ::: {#0c85aacf .cell execution_count=23} ``` {.python .cell-code} x = 1 if (x < 1): print("x is less than 1") elif (x > 1): print("x is greater than 1") else: print("x is equal to 1") ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` x is equal to 1 ``` ::: ::: ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} ::: {#0ee33eb8 .cell execution_count=24} ``` {.python .cell-code} x = 2 if (x < 1): print("x is less than 1") elif (x > 1): print("x is greater than 1") else: print("x is equal to 1") ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` x is greater than 1 ``` ::: ::: ::: :::: ## Double equals equality - I call it *single-equals assignment* because sometimes we check if a variable is precisely equal to some value. - That is somewhat confusingly done with `==` *double equals equality* test. :::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="50%"} ::: {#b894cbdf .cell execution_count=25} ``` {.python .cell-code} x = 1 if (x == 1): print("x is equal to 1") else: print("x is not equal to 1") ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` x is equal to 1 ``` ::: ::: ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} ::: {#2c56e2a9 .cell execution_count=26} ``` {.python .cell-code} x = 2 if (x == 1): print("x is equal to 1") else: print("x is not equal to 1") ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` x is not equal to 1 ``` ::: ::: ::: :::: ## Double ** Exponentation - Doubling is used in a few other cases. - Double asterisk `**` is exponentiation. ::: {#6b219db7 .cell execution_count=27} ``` {.python .cell-code} 5 ** 2 ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=501} ``` 25 ``` ::: ::: - We note that `^` - sometimes used for exponentiation - is something different (and confusing!) in Python. ::: {#2d2ef007 .cell execution_count=28} ``` {.python .cell-code} 5 ^ 2 ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=502} ``` 7 ``` ::: ::: - Always use `**` ## Piecewise - We can finally write the piecewise expression! :::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="50%"} $$ \begin{cases} 9x^2 + 5 & x < 4 \\ 9 & 4 \leq x \leq 8 \\ 2 - x & x > 8 \end{cases} $$ $$ \{-1, 4, 5, 8, 11\} $$ ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} ::: {#62ec5583 .cell execution_count=29} ``` {.python .cell-code} x = 11 if (x < 4): print(9 * x ** 2 + 5) elif (4 <= x <= 8): print(9) elif (x > 8): print(2 - x) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` -9 ``` ::: ::: ::: :::: # Code Reuse ## Recycle - It is still extremely tedious to either: - Copy-paste, or - Type more than once. - Also very annoying/difficult to write them many lines without error! - We introduce the `def` keyword to define `functions` - A way to reuse code we have already written. ## `def` - We recall we use `print` in a multi-line. ::: {#53b579da .cell execution_count=30} ``` {.python .cell-code} def double(x): print(x + x) ``` ::: - `def` + *some function name* + `(` + *some variable name* + `):` ::: {#42e07a3a .cell execution_count=31} ``` {.python .cell-code} double(7) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` 14 ``` ::: ::: - "Call" functions the same way we call `print` - with parens. ## Metaphor - `def` is like asking a friend for something. - "Hey can you add `x` and `x` together?" - `print` is how your friend tells you the result. - "Can you print out the result of `x + x` for me?" ## `return` - It is more common to use `return` than `print` in a function. - When we call a function, we can think of it as expression with some value. - That value is defined by the value that is return. :::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="50%"} ::: {#e0fd28af .cell execution_count=32} ``` {.python .cell-code} def six_gt_five_print(): print(True) if (six_gt_five_print()): print(123) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` True ``` ::: ::: ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} ::: {#147119bf .cell execution_count=33} ``` {.python .cell-code} def six_gt_five_print(): return True if (six_gt_five_print()): print(123) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` 123 ``` ::: ::: ::: :::: ## Example - Suppose an interest rate doubles our savings every ~7 years. - How much savings in 14 years? ::: {#da3c091a .cell execution_count=34} ``` {.python .cell-code} savings = 10 double(savings) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` 20 ``` ::: ::: ## Use return ::: {#619cec0c .cell execution_count=35} ``` {.python .cell-code} def double(x): return x + x ``` ::: - Now, `double(savings)` becomes equal to `x + x` ::: {#1179e597 .cell execution_count=36} ``` {.python .cell-code} savings = 10 savings = double(savings) savings ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=510} ``` 20 ``` ::: ::: ::: {#98c353fa .cell execution_count=37} ``` {.python .cell-code} double(savings) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=511} ``` 40 ``` ::: ::: - Or even ::: {#f4f2392e .cell execution_count=38} ``` {.python .cell-code} double(double(10)) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=512} ``` 40 ``` ::: ::: ## Piecewise - We can finally write the piecewise function (was: expression)! - Function: use many times in many expressions - Expression: evaluate once and get one answer :::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="50%"} $$ \begin{cases} 9x^2 + 5 & x < 4 \\ 9 & 4 \leq x \leq 8 \\ 2 - x & x > 8 \end{cases} $$ $$ \{-1, 4, 5, 8, 11\} $$ ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} ::: {#921a378d .cell execution_count=39} ``` {.python .cell-code} def piecewise(x): if (x < 4): return 9 * x ** 2 + 5 elif (4 <= x <= 8): return 9 elif (x > 8): return 2 - x ``` ::: ::: {#44712c40 .cell execution_count=40} ``` {.python .cell-code} piecewise(4) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=514} ``` 9 ``` ::: ::: ::: :::: # Iteration ## Tedium - This is still quite tedious. ::: {#1ede6df5 .cell execution_count=41} ``` {.python .cell-code} piecewise(-1) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=515} ``` 14 ``` ::: ::: ::: {#6eae47e6 .cell execution_count=42} ``` {.python .cell-code} piecewise(4) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=516} ``` 9 ``` ::: ::: ::: {#ead5b854 .cell execution_count=43} ``` {.python .cell-code} piecewise(5) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=517} ``` 9 ``` ::: ::: ::: {#b521b9fe .cell execution_count=44} ``` {.python .cell-code} piecewise(8) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=518} ``` 9 ``` ::: ::: ::: {#7b191cfd .cell execution_count=45} ``` {.python .cell-code} piecewise(11) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=519} ``` -9 ``` ::: ::: ## Sets - This is a *set*: $$ \{-1, 4, 5, 8, 11\} $$ - A set is an *unordered* collection of *elements*. - In this case, elements are integers - whole numbers. - Python can also recognize sets! ::: {#1f5fb5ee .cell execution_count=46} ``` {.python .cell-code} {-1, 4, 5, 8, 11} ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=520} ``` {-1, 4, 5, 8, 11} ``` ::: ::: ## Type - To be sure that is, in fact, a set, we use the helpful built-in `type()` to ask Python. ::: {#89592323 .cell execution_count=47} ``` {.python .cell-code} s = {-1, 4, 5, 8, 11} type(s) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=521} ``` set ``` ::: ::: - We have also worked with **int**egers. ::: {#0786f298 .cell execution_count=48} ``` {.python .cell-code} type(1) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=522} ``` int ``` ::: ::: - And ***bool**eans* - `True` and `False` values. ::: {#19973ba1 .cell execution_count=49} ``` {.python .cell-code} type(1 == 1) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=523} ``` bool ``` ::: ::: ## Loops - With a set, do something *to each element* - In Python, use a `for` loop: - The `for` keyword - The name to refer to an element, like `e` or `x` - The `in` keyword - The set/collection (or its variable name) - The `:` colon special character - An indented new line of code ## Example - for element in collection - do thing ::: {#2e8d6277 .cell execution_count=50} ``` {.python .cell-code} for e in {-1, 4, 5, 8, 11}: print(piecewise(e)) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` 9 9 9 -9 14 ``` ::: ::: - What do you see? ## Example - What if we just try to print the elements? - Easier to think about! ::: {#52ad7161 .cell execution_count=51} ``` {.python .cell-code} for e in {-1, 4, 5, 8, 11}: print(e) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` 4 5 8 11 -1 ``` ::: ::: - What do you see? ## Ordering - Recall: "A set is an *unordered* collection of *elements*". - We need to put things in order! - The most common way to do this in Python is with a *list*. - Almost the same as sets, just use "boxy brackets" `[]` ::: {#667cd3da .cell execution_count=52} ``` {.python .cell-code} type([1,2,3]) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=526} ``` list ``` ::: ::: ## Example - for element in collection - do thing ::: {#3cb0cc26 .cell execution_count=53} ``` {.python .cell-code} for e in [-1, 4, 5, 8, 11]: print(piecewise(e)) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` 14 9 9 9 -9 ``` ::: ::: - What do you see? ## Seeing lists - We can also use lists to print multiple values! - Very helpful for keeping track of things! ::: {#5ed26286 .cell execution_count=54} ``` {.python .cell-code} for e in [-1, 4, 5, 8, 11]: print([e, piecewise(e)]) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [-1, 14] [4, 9] [5, 9] [8, 9] [11, -9] ``` ::: ::: ## Updating lists - Each element is a lot like a variable. - They just have a name *and* number, use `[]` - The initial element is number `0` (*not* 1) ::: {#cd1c38d9 .cell execution_count=55} ``` {.python .cell-code} xs = [-1, 4, 5, 8, 11] xs[0] ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=529} ``` -1 ``` ::: ::: - And like variables, we can assign a value with `=` ::: {#118dd92d .cell execution_count=56} ``` {.python .cell-code} xs[0] = -2 xs ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=530} ``` [-2, 4, 5, 8, 11] ``` ::: ::: ## Metaphor - Think of a list like a block in a neighborhood. - Perhaps to "400" block or "8000" - The house on the corner has the block number. - 400 1st St, 8000 9th Ave - Latter houses have higher numbers. - 404 1st St, 8019 9th Ave ## Adding lists - Lists also helpfully support addition with `+` ::: {#aaba79c4 .cell execution_count=57} ``` {.python .cell-code} [-1] + [4, 5, 8, 11] ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=531} ``` [-1, 4, 5, 8, 11] ``` ::: ::: - We often use this to make new lists. ::: {#5acf000c .cell execution_count=58} ``` {.python .cell-code} result = [] for e in [-1, 4, 5, 8, 11]: result = result + [piecewise(e)] result ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=532} ``` [14, 9, 9, 9, -9] ``` ::: ::: - This pattern also works with numbers! ::: {#ebd34a00 .cell execution_count=59} ``` {.python .cell-code} x = 0 x = x + 1 x ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=533} ``` 1 ``` ::: ::: ## Careful! - We cannot add numbers directly to lists - `[1] + 2` doesn't work! - I think of this as adding a house to block without having an address for it. - Where would the house go? - To add a house to block, we need to have a new "lot" for the house to be on. # Exercise ## Income tax -
